questions.text: Which of the following is the most common protein mutation seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
The most common mutations in HCM are those affecting the myosin heavy chain.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disease. In the majority of cases it is due to missense mutations in the following two sarcolemmal protein genes: 

  • Myosin binding protein C (MYBC)
  • Beta myosin heavy chain (MYH7)

Option B: Alpha-tropomyosin mutation is seen in HCM but is not common.

Options C and D: Mutations in cardiac troponin C and titin are associated with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).

questions.text: A 19-year-old basketball player collapses during a match and regains consciousness several minutes later. He reveals that he has had similar episodes before. His older brother, a soccer player, had died suddenly at the age of 22 years during a soccer game due to a heart ailment. Which of the following is least likely to be found on echocardiography in this patient?

choices.text: Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve
Mitral regurgitation with anteriorly directed regurgitant jet

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of exercise intolerance (syncope) in the patient and family history of sudden cardiac death in his elder brother at a young age is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Mitral regurgitation with posteriorly directed regurgitant jet is usually seen on echocardiogram in HCM. ECG and echocardiogram are used to confirm the diagnosis of HCM.

HCM is characterized by myofiber disarray in the heart, resulting in a hypertrophic myocardium. The hypertrophy leads to the following pathophysiological changes in HCM: 

  • Diastolic dysfunction - presenting as exercise intolerance
  • Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve
    • The hypertrophied muscles result in a narrow outflow tract
    • This leads to the production of a high-velocity jet pulling the mitral leaflets towards the septum posteriorly 
    • SAM leads to mitral regurgitation
  • Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction

Echocardiography features of HCM are as follows:

  • Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm 
  • Hypertrophied heart more confined to the interventricular septum resulting in banana-shaped ventricular cavity

questions.text: While evaluating a young man for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy you hear a harsh and late peaking systolic ejection murmur at the lower left sternal border. On performing which of the following maneuvers, the intensity of this murmur is expected to decrease?
questions.solution:
Squatting increases the preload and afterload thereby decreasing the outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur in HCM.

In HCM left ventricular size is small, thus the approximation of the interventricular septum with the mitral valve increases. The following mechanisms further increase this approximation and increase blood outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur:

  • A decrease in left ventricular cavity volume or pressure (decreased preload)
  • A decrease in systemic vascular resistance and/or arterial pressure (decreased afterload)
  • Increase in left ventricular contractility

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient has been diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is not a major risk factor for sudden death in this condition?

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death

questions.solution:
Atrial fibrillation in HCM is not associated with increased HCM-related mortality. It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life.

Among HCM patients, the greatest risk for sudden cardiac death is seen in patients who have sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT). These patients must undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention.  

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Sudden Death in HCM

Risk factors for sudden death in HCM:

  • History of cardiac arrest or spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia
  • Syncope
  • Family history of sudden cardiac death
  • Spontaneous nonsustained ventricular tachycardia
  • LV thickness > 30mm
  • Abnormal blood pressure response to exercise

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV hypertrophy. A doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Digoxin should be avoided as it may increase contractility and worsen obstruction.

Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and thus contraindicated in HCM are:

  • Digoxin
  • Inotropes
  • Nitrates
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine)

Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM. Disopyramide and amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.

questions.text: Which is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life. 

Treatment of atrial fibrillation in HCM:

  • Amiodarone - drug of choice
  • Disopyramide
  • Radiofrequency ablation for medically refractory cases
  • Anticoagulation to prevent embolic events

Note: A sustained arrhythmia is one that lasts for >30 seconds.

questions.text: You are counseling the parents of a 15-year-old boy who was recently diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. What is the recommendation regarding his participation in sports?

choices.text: Participation in competitive sports is not recommended
Only non-contact competitive sports are allowed
Non-contact competitive sports with beta-blocker therapy is allowed
High-intensity exercise is acceptable with verapamil therapy

questions.solution:
Participation in competitive sports is not recommended for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

The following general measures are advised for patients with HCM:

  • Patients are advised against engaging in competitive athletics or vigorous physical activities
  • Maintaining low to moderate levels of exercise as a part of a healthy lifestyle has been proven to be beneficial
  • Adequate hydration at all times

Note: Non-contact sports are those sports wherein the participants are physically separated with almost no physical contact (ex: tennis, badminton) between them. Contact sports involve some form of physical contact between the participants (ex: wrestling, boxing)

questions.text: A 65-year-old Japanese woman was brought to the emergency department with worsening angina and palpitations. Her physical examination was normal. ECG showed giant T wave inversions and coronary angiography was normal. Left ventriculography showed spade-like deformity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of giant T wave inversions and spade-like deformity on left ventriculography points to a diagnosis of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is also called Yamaguchi syndrome. It is characterized by hypertrophy of the myocardium, predominantly in the left ventricular apex. It was first described in the Japanese population and is uncommon in other populations.

The symptoms are milder and the risk of sudden cardiac death is lower than in the traditional septal form of HCM.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of chest pain and collapsed and was later declared brought dead by the hospital. His family says he was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden heart failure in a previously healthy person under a stressful situation is suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients can present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

ECHO reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a Takotsubo (pot for catching octopus).  The ECG changes can mimic myocardial infarction but changes extend beyond a particular coronary arterial territory. Coronary angiography, therefore, may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. (Option B)

It is a self-limiting disorder resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning resembling a Takotsubo pot. 

Other options:

Option A: Infective cardiomyopathy: The most common causes of infective myocarditis are viral infections and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is associated with Chagas' disease. Acute viral myocarditis often presents with symptoms and signs of heart failure, although it can also manifest as chest pain and show electrocardiogram (ECG) changes resembling pericarditis or acute myocardial infarction. In Chagas' disease, specific features include abnormalities in the conduction system, particularly dysfunction of the sinus node and AV node, as well as the right bundle branch block.

Option C: Dilated cardiomyopathy: It is the most common cardiomyopathy and is predominantly characterised by systolic dysfunction. Though it may present acutely, it progresses chronically. The familial form is due to mutations in TTN gene which encode the sarcomeric protein titin. Other etiologocal agents include alcohol, infective myocarditis, doxorubicin, hemochromatosis and sarcoidosis. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder and is a prominent cause of sudden death before the age of 35 years. Family history is commonly present, a sarcomere mutation is present in ~50% of patients. Sudden death can be due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation. Risk factors for sudden death in this disease include young age, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, failure of blood pressure to increase during exercise, recent (within 6 months) syncope, ventricular wall thickness >3 cm, and possibly the severity of LV outflow obstruction.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is the probable diagnosis when the observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match ECG changes.

Myocardial stunning is a state where certain segments of the myocardium (usually corresponding to an area of major coronary occlusion) show forms of contractile abnormality (dysfunction) on echocardiography.

In Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, while the ECG changes mimic a myocardial infarction(MI), the left ventricular dysfunction extends well beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG. Ventriculography shows apical dilation with basal contraction.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs typically in older women and is associated with a sudden increase in emotional or physical stress, presenting with hypotension, chest pain with ECG changes of acute MI, and pulmonary edema. Its also known as apical ballooning syndrome or acute stress-induced cardiomyopathy.

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction with reduced contractility and ejection fraction, most commonly seen in amyloidosis, and enlarged ventricles on imaging with low-voltage ECG complexes.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is a type of familial dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), having defects in desmosomal proteins, affecting the ventricles showing thin ventricular walls on Echo, epsilon waves, and low voltage ECG complexes.

Option D: Pericardial tamponade is characterized by hypotension, muffled heart sounds and increased jugular venous pressure with muffled heart sounds with total electrical alternans and sinus tachycardia in ECG.

questions.text: A 17-year-old Chinese boy presented with prolonged fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in the legs. His echocardiography was suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies can explain his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency. It is endemic dilated cardiomyopathy that affects children and women of childbearing age in some areas in China.

The nutritional deficiencies that can lead to cardiomyopathy are:

  • Thiamine
  • Selenium
  • Carnitine
  • Calcium
  • Phosphate
  • Magnesium

questions.text: Endomyocardial biopsy of a patient shows vacuolar degeneration and myofibrillar loss. Which of the following drugs may be responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Endomyocardial biopsy showing vacuolar degeneration and myofibrillar loss is seen in cardiotoxicity due to anthracyclines (doxorubicin).

Difference between cardiotoxicity due to anthracyclins and trastuzumab:

Anthracyclins Trastuzumab
Irreversible Reversible
Dose-dependent Not dose-dependent
Biopsy shows myocyte destruction Biopsy does not show myocyte destruction

questions.text: In which of the following patients, the risk of developing peripartum cardiomyopathy is less?

choices.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman with an obstetric score of G2P1

questions.solution:
Low parity is not a risk factor for peripartum cardiomyopathy. Increased parity is a risk factor.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops during the last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery. The risk factors are:

  • Increased maternal age
  • Increased parity
  • Twin pregnancy
  • Malnutrition
  • Use of tocolytic therapy for premature labor
  • Preeclampsia or toxemia of pregnancy

questions.text: A young male patient presents with progressive dyspnea and weakness. He gives a history of fever, myalgia, and sore throat one week ago.  To further evaluate him as per Dallas criteria, which of the following tests need to be performed?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective myocarditis. The Dallas criteria used for the diagnosis of myocarditis is based on endomyocardial biopsy. It is used to define the disease.

Active myocarditis is defined as an inflammatory infiltrate of the myocardium with necrosis and/or degeneration of adjacent myocytes not typical of the ischemic damage associated with coronary artery disease.

Borderline myocarditis is the term used when the inflammatory infiltrate is too sparse or myocyte injury is not demonstrated.

questions.text: Which is the most common infective cause of myocarditis?
questions.solution:
The most common infective cause of myocarditis is Trypanosoma cruzi causing Chagas disease.

Infective myocarditis is most commonly associated with viruses (adenovirus, coxsackie B virus, HHV-6) and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi.

The most common noninfective cause of myocarditis is sarcoidosis.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management?
Clinical findings  Management
a. Pulsus bisferiens 1. Beta-blockers are given
b. Pulsus alternans 2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated
c. Ejection systolic murmur 3. ICD is indicated
d. Murmur increases on standing 4. ICD is contraindicated
e. Murmur decreases on standing
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient with a history of sudden collapse following physical activity along with ECG findings of V5, V6 inversion, and prominent inverted T-waves, and 2D echocardiography showing the systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet point toward a diagnosis of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM).

In HCM, clinical examination may reveal pulsus bisferiens and an ejection systolic murmur that increases on standing.

Beta-blockers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICD) are used in the management.

HCM is a leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with variable penetrance. HCM is characterized by the thickening of the septal myocardium below the aortic valve leading to obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.

Symptoms:

  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Syncope
  • Angina, palpitations, cardiac arrhythmias
  • Sudden cardiac death (particularly during or after intense physical activity)

 

 

Examination:

  • Systolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex or lower left sternal border

ECG findings:

  • P wave abnormalities 
  • Prominent abnormal Q waves
  • Deeply inverted T waves 

Echocardiography findings:

 

  • LV wall thickness ≥15 mm
  • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet
  • Mitral regurgitation

 

Treatment: 

  • Beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are the first-line treatment 
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) - indicated when the history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia is present
